David, I agree with everything you are saying except the moving 
animals th=
ing. This is a frozen moment of perhaps decision or 
indecision. Only subje=
ctive of course. Lighting, well is it the time 
of day or the shade of the =
tree? John




--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "David Zincavage" <jdz@=
...> 
wrote:
>
> Barry,
> 
> I just remembered that we never finished discu=
ssing that great Ko 
Kinko tsuba with the Kasugane motif. 
> 
> I'm particu=
larly fond of the deer. I've added to the photo on the 
web-page an illustr=
ation from a book on Paleolithic art, describing 
the same combination of p=
erspectives we see in the deer on the 
tsuba.  This very ancient approach t=
o perspective is not 
naturalistic in the way we are normally accustomed to=
 seeing, but I 
think, in the case of this tsuba, it very successfully comm=
unicates 
the kind of imperfect image of deer we receive, looking from a 
d=
istance in less than optimum light at moving animals. 
> 
> I think the imp=
erfection of the perspective makes this tsuba more 
exciting than a it woul=
d be if it featured a much more literally 
modeled image.  And the archaic =
quality, the comparative roughness 
of the representation of the deer, on t=
he elegant kinko background 
is more dramatic by the virtue of the extreme =
contrast between image 
and background.             
>     
> 
> http://zin=
cavage.org/KoKinkoKasugane.htm
> 
> 
> David Zincavage
> 
> 
>

riginal Message -----

oups.com

tostudy] Re: in defense of the ugly bird or 
seeking more " punishment "

> 
>   I have followed this discussion with great interest and will 
have =
to go over it
>   again I'm sure, but I clearly see what Milt is talking ab=
out.  
To find a stiffer
>   deer one would have to go to the tundra...
> 
=
>   I recall well a tsuba that I found many years ago.  It was a 
small, co=
pper
>   sanmai awase (if I correctly remember a phrase I haven't uttered 
=
for 15 or more
>   years!) with a touch of silver (tin??) showing stylised =

(stamped?) waves with a
>   creature on it that I always thought was an "o=
ver-endowed 
rabbit", but Bob
>   Haynes told me was a fox!!  I wrote to Bo=
b when I saw a similar 
tsuba in one of
>   his catalogues.  I was amazed w=
hen he said this was a very early 
style of tsuba
>   ca 1300 - 1400.  I ha=
d it for years, often looking at it and 
saying "Do I like
>   it, or do I =
not??"  Same thing with this deer kinko.  I have 
gazed at Pete
>   Klein's=
 image on yahoo (I actually have the Lundren Collection 
book, but it's
>  =
 out on loan to a 'kinko' mate) for a long time on this sleepless 
night, a=
nd I
>   ask myself the same question all over again.  So David Z, if I 
co=
uld ask you a
>   question, when you say "I don't collect kinko at all,  bu=
t this 
is one of a
>   small number of cases which, granted a opportunity,=
 would lead 
me to alter my
>   policy" I have to ask you "WHY??"  Please e=
xplain.
> 
>   If I found this very tsuba I would think it was junk.  I don=
't 
have to tell you
>   why.  Or do I??  The design spilling into the sepp=
adai I have 
only seen on tsuba
>   I didn't care for.  The wobbly surface =
and incredibly bad nanako 
would kill it
>   for me.  And the stiff deer do=
esn't do anything for me at all.  
However, I would
>   look at the larger =
than usual kozuka ana and opine "Hmmm, maybe 
it's early".
>   Back to my q=
uestion to myself "Do I like it, or do I not".  If I 
don't like it,
>   I =
don't collect it, no matter what the aesthetes say.
> 
>   Now, this puts m=
e into the rustic class, I know, but there is a 
point to this
>   that is =
not all derisory or derogatory.  It is this.  It is easy 
to pick
>   excel=
lent work amongst Edo period tsuba , even in the iron "wabi-
sabi" class,
>=
   but the archaic styles, the transition between (if we might say) 
concep=
tual
>   forerunners and the refined later schools is much, much more 
diff=
icult.  Or is
>   it??  Recall here Milt's hawk tsuba that lead to the pres=
ent 
discussion.  And I
>   can show you a tsuba that a well-educated (tsub=
a knowledge) mate 
of mine
>   dismissed as "late, possibly 1920s".  It is =
a masterwork of late 
Edo/early Meiji
>   and belongs to a friend of mine. =
 If he gives permission I'll 
put up some images
>   of it.
> 
>   So, to b=
ring this to a close, are there any others inhabiting 
the same closet as
>=
   I???  I know I'm lacking an ability, an aesthetic if you like, 
to appre=
ciate the
>   stiff deer kinko in question and it worries me.  It seems 
wi=
thout thorough study
>   and training many tsuba in this time frame would i=
ndeed be 
considered junk and
>   sold off, possibly to an ignominious fate=
.  The other kinko that 
Pete shows in
>   two images at the same link does=
 "speak to me".  It is from the 
same time frame
>   and I find it elegant =
and refined and would collect it.  I think 
this discussion
>   parallels t=
he Sue Koto kazuuchimono line of thinking with 
blades - I don't
>   collec=
t those either...
> 
>   Barry Thomas
